user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_request_line:
```c
static bool
get_request_line (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  const int discp_lvl = c->daemon->client_discipline;
  /* Parse whitespace in URI, special parsing of the request line */
  const bool wsp_in_uri = (0 >= discp_lvl);
  /* Keep whitespace in URI, give app URI with whitespace instead of
     automatic redirect to fixed URI */
  const bool wsp_in_uri_keep = (-2 >= discp_lvl);

  if (! get_request_line_inner (c))
  {
    /* End of the request line has not been found yet */
    mhd_assert ((! wsp_in_uri) || NULL == c->rq.version);
    if ((NULL != c->rq.version) &&
        (HTTP_VER_LEN <
         (c->rq.hdrs.rq_line.proc_pos
          - (size_t) (c->rq.version - c->read_buffer))))
    {
      c->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_INVALID;
      transmit_error_response_static (c,
                                      MHD_HTTP_BAD_REQUEST,
                                      REQUEST_MALFORMED);
      return true; /* Error in the request */
    }
    return false;
  }
  if (MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_LINE_RECEIVING < c->state)
    return true; /* Error in the request */

  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_LINE_RECEIVING == c->state);
  mhd_assert (NULL == c->rq.url);
  mhd_assert (0 == c->rq.url_len);
  mhd_assert (NULL != c->rq.hdrs.rq_line.rq_tgt);
  if (0 != c->rq.hdrs.rq_line.num_ws_in_uri)
  {
    if (! wsp_in_uri)
    {
      transmit_error_response_static (c,
                                      MHD_HTTP_BAD_REQUEST,
                                      RQ_TARGET_INVALID_CHAR);
      return true; /* Error in the request */
    }
    if (! wsp_in_uri_keep)
    {
      send_redirect_fixed_rq_target (c);
      return true; /* Error in the request */
    }
  }
  if (! process_request_target (c))
    return true; /* Error in processing */

  c->state = MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_LINE_RECEIVED;
  return true;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (! process_request_target (c))
    return true; /* Error in processing */
explanation:
The fragments above are selected because they contain control-flow and condition combinations that can make code paths effectively unreachable or rely on implicit relationships between variables that should be validated (for example: the relationship between c->state and the assertions, the HTTP_VER_LEN check when get_request_line_inner() reports an incomplete line, and the interaction of wsp_in_uri and wsp_in_uri_keep with num_ws_in_uri). These locations should be inspected to ensure no code is logically impossible to reach under any valid program state.

Other parts of the function were not selected because they are simple straight-line code or obvious returns (final state assignment and return true, simple transmit/send calls guarded by the conditions above, and the top-level boolean computations of wsp_in_uri/wsp_in_uri_keep themselves are simple evaluations rather than dead code). Assertions alone were flagged only where they are adjacent to a conditional that could make the asserted condition impossible; isolated asserts or simple assignments that do not create unreachable branches were not included to avoid false positives.
